Submodules

swap_puzzle.graph module

This is the graph module.

class swap_puzzle.graph.Graph(nodes=[])

Bases: object

A class representing undirected graphs as adjacency lists.

Methods

add_edge(node1, node2)

Adds an edge to the graph.

bfs(src, dst)

Finds a shortest path from src to dst by BFS.

graph_from_file(file_name)

Reads a text file and returns the graph as an object of the Graph class.
add_edge(node1, node2)

Adds an edge to the graph. Graphs are not oriented, hence an edge is added to the adjacency list of both end nodes. When adding an edge between two nodes, if one of the ones does not exist it is added to the list of nodes.

bfs(src, dst)

Finds a shortest path from src to dst by BFS.

classmethod graph_from_file(file_name)

Reads a text file and returns the graph as an object of the Graph class.

The file should have the following format:

The first line of the file is ‘n m’ The next m lines have ‘node1 node2’

The nodes (node1, node2) should be named 1..n

swap_puzzle.grid module

This is the grid module. It contains the Grid class and its associated methods.

class swap_puzzle.grid.Grid(m: int, n: int, initial_state: list[list[int]] = None)

Bases: object

A class representing the grid from the swap puzzle. It supports rectangular grids.

Methods

get_cell(i, j)

Get the value in the cell (i, j)

grid_from_file(file_name)

Creates a grid object initialized with the information from the file file_name.

is_coord_2tuple(obj)

Check if an object is a 2-tuple representing (the coordinates of) a cell in the grid.

is_sorted()

Checks is the current state of the grid is sorted and returns the answer as a boolean.

swap(cell1, cell2)

Swap (the values of) two cells.

swap_seq(cell_pair_list)

Executes a sequence of swaps.
get_cell(i: int, j: int) → int

Get the value in the cell (i, j)

Parameters:
i: int

First coordinate of the cell

j: int

Second coordinate of the cell

Returns:
Value of the given cell
Raises:
InvalidPositionException

Raised if the given cell is invalid

classmethod grid_from_file(file_name)

Creates a grid object initialized with the information from the file file_name.

is_coord_2tuple(obj: object) → bool

Check if an object is a 2-tuple representing (the coordinates of) a cell in the grid.

Parameters:
obj:

Object to check

Returns:
bool

True if the object is a 2-tuple (i, j) with 0 <= i < m and 0 <= j < n (false otherwise)

is_sorted() → bool

Checks is the current state of the grid is sorted and returns the answer as a boolean.

Returns:
bool

True if the grid is sorted (false otherwise)

swap(cell1: (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>), cell2: (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)) → None

Swap (the values of) two cells.

Raises an exception if the swap is not allowed. The cells must be in the format (i, j) where i is the line and j the column number of the cell and be adjacent.

Parameters:
cell1: (int, int)

First cell to swap

cell2: (int, int)

Second cell to swap

Raises:
InvalidPositionException

If one of the given parameters corresponds to an invalid cell coordinates

SwapNotAllowedException

Raised if the swap is not allowed.

swap_seq(cell_pair_list: list[tuple]) → None

Executes a sequence of swaps.

Parameters:
cell_pair_list: list[tuple]

The list of swaps, each swap being a tuple of two cells (each cell being a tuple of integers).

Raises:
SwapNotAllowedException

Raised if the given list of swaps is not a valid list of 2-tuples, or if a swap is not allowed.

swap_puzzle.naivesolver module

class swap_puzzle.naivesolver.NaiveSolver(grid: Grid)

Bases: Solver

A naive solver, doing swaps of adjacent cases.

Methods

snake(p)

Return the coordinates of the p-th case if we iterate the case in a "snake" way.

get_solution
get_solution() → None
snake(p: int) -> (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)

Return the coordinates of the p-th case if we iterate the case in a “snake” way. For instance on a 3x3 grid, the cases would be :

1 2 3 6 5 4 7 8 9

Parameters:

p – an integer for the p-th case

Returns:

The p-th case (i, j) coordinates

swap_puzzle.naivesolver2 module

class swap_puzzle.naivesolver2.NaiveSolver2(grid: Grid)

Bases: Solver

A naive solver, doing swaps of adjacent cases.

Methods

get_solution()

Solves the grid and returns the sequence of swaps at the format [((i1, j1), (i2, j2)), ((i1', j1'), (i2', j2')), ...].

grid_to_arr(g)

Returns a flattened grid with correct junctions between lines [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] -> [1,2,3,6,5,4]

reverse_arr(arr)

Reverses the elements of a list, modifies the list directly.

snake(p)

Return the coordinates of the p-th case if we iterate the case in a "snake" way.

insertion_sort
get_solution() → None

Solves the grid and returns the sequence of swaps at the format [((i1, j1), (i2, j2)), ((i1’, j1’), (i2’, j2’)), …].

grid_to_arr(g: Grid) → list[int]

Returns a flattened grid with correct junctions between lines [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] -> [1,2,3,6,5,4]

insertion_sort(l: list) → list
reverse_arr(arr: list)

Reverses the elements of a list, modifies the list directly.

snake(p: int) -> (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)

Return the coordinates of the p-th case if we iterate the case in a “snake” way. For instance on a 3x3 grid, the cases would be :

1 2 3 6 5 4 7 8 9

Parameters:

p – an integer for the p-th case

Returns:

The p-th case (i, j) coordinates

swap_puzzle.solver module

class swap_puzzle.solver.Solver(max_calls: int = 1000, callback: ~collections.abc.Callable[[(<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>), (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)], None] = <function Solver.<lambda>>)

Bases: object

Solver class. Helps control the permitted operations on the grid and retrieve the list of steps.

Attributes:
max_calls: int, optional

Maximum number of calls, default is 1000

callback: Callable[[(int, int), (int, int)], None], optional

Function called when a swap is operated on the grid. Default does nothing.

Methods

get_solution
get_solution(grid: Grid) → None
